trans-unit.source: Derby JDBC database connection URL

seg-source.mrk: Derby JDBC database connection URL

target.mrk: Derby JDBC database connection URL

trans-unit.source: A Java application using the JDBC API establishes a connection to a database by obtaining a Connection object.

seg-source.mrk: A Java application using the JDBC API establishes a connection to a database by obtaining a Connection object.

target.mrk: A Java application using the JDBC API establishes a connection to a database by obtaining a Connection object.

trans-unit.source: Database connection URL

target.mrk: Database connection URL

trans-unit.source: Database connection URL

seg-source.mrk: Database connection URL

target.mrk: Database connection URL

trans-unit.source: features common to embedded and client/server versions

seg-source.mrk: features common to embedded and client/server versions

target.mrk: features common to embedded and client/server versions

trans-unit.source: The standard way to obtain a Connection object is to call the method DriverManager.getConnection, which takes a String containing a connection URL (uniform resource locator). A JDBC connection URL provides a way of identifying a database. It also allows you to perform a number of high-level tasks, such as creating a database or shutting down the system.

seg-source.mrk: The standard way to obtain a Connection object is to call the method DriverManager.getConnection, which takes a String containing a connection URL (uniform resource locator).
A JDBC connection URL provides a way of identifying a database.
It also allows you to perform a number of high-level tasks, such as creating a database or shutting down the system.

target.mrk: The standard way to obtain a Connection object is to call the method DriverManager.getConnection, which takes a String containing a connection URL (uniform resource locator).
A JDBC connection URL provides a way of identifying a database.
It also allows you to perform a number of high-level tasks, such as creating a database or shutting down the system.

trans-unit.source: An application in an embedded environment uses a different connection URL from that used by applications using the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server in a client/server environment. See the <cite><ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citadmin"></ph></cite> for more information on the Network Server.

seg-source.mrk: An application in an embedded environment uses a different connection URL from that used by applications using the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server in a client/server environment.
See the <cite><ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citadmin"></ph></cite> for more information on the Network Server.

target.mrk: An application in an embedded environment uses a different connection URL from that used by applications using the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server in a client/server environment.
See the <cite><ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citadmin"></ph></cite> for more information on the Network Server.

trans-unit.source: However, all versions of the connection URL (which you can use for tasks besides connecting to a database) have common features:

seg-source.mrk: However, all versions of the connection URL (which you can use for tasks besides connecting to a database) have common features:

target.mrk: However, all versions of the connection URL (which you can use for tasks besides connecting to a database) have common features:

trans-unit.source: you can specify the name of the database you want to connect to

seg-source.mrk: you can specify the name of the database you want to connect to

target.mrk: you can specify the name of the database you want to connect to

trans-unit.source: you can specify a number of attributes and values that allow you to accomplish tasks. For more information about what you can specify with the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> connection URL, see <xref href="rdevdvlp22102.dita#rdevdvlp22102"></xref>.

seg-source.mrk: you can specify a number of attributes and values that allow you to accomplish tasks.
For more information about what you can specify with the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> connection URL, see <xref href="rdevdvlp22102.dita#rdevdvlp22102"></xref>.

target.mrk: you can specify a number of attributes and values that allow you to accomplish tasks.
For more information about what you can specify with the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> connection URL, see <xref href="rdevdvlp22102.dita#rdevdvlp22102"></xref>.

trans-unit.source: The connection URL syntax is as follows:

seg-source.mrk: The connection URL syntax is as follows:

target.mrk: The connection URL syntax is as follows:

trans-unit.source: jdbc:derby:[subsubprotocol:][databaseName][;attribute=value]*

seg-source.mrk: jdbc:derby:[subsubprotocol:][databaseName][;attribute=value]*

target.mrk: jdbc:derby:[subsubprotocol:][databaseName][;attribute=value]*

trans-unit.source: Subsubprotocol, which is not typically specified, determines how looks for a database: in a directory, in memory, in a class path, or in a jar file. Subsubprotocol is one of the following:

seg-source.mrk: Subsubprotocol, which is not typically specified, determines how looks for a database: in a directory, in memory, in a class path, or in a jar file.
Subsubprotocol is one of the following:

target.mrk: Subsubprotocol, which is not typically specified, determines how looks for a database: in a directory, in memory, in a class path, or in a jar file.
Subsubprotocol is one of the following:

trans-unit.source: directory: The default, which need not be specified explicitly. The database is in the file system, and the path is either relative to the system directory or absolute.

seg-source.mrk: directory: The default, which need not be specified explicitly.
The database is in the file system, and the path is either relative to the system directory or absolute.

target.mrk: directory: The default, which need not be specified explicitly.
The database is in the file system, and the path is either relative to the system directory or absolute.

trans-unit.source: memory: Databases exist only in main memory and are not written to disk. An in-memory database may be useful when there is no need to persist the database -- for example, in some testing situations.

seg-source.mrk: memory: Databases exist only in main memory and are not written to disk.
An in-memory database may be useful when there is no need to persist the database -- for example, in some testing situations.

target.mrk: memory: Databases exist only in main memory and are not written to disk.
An in-memory database may be useful when there is no need to persist the database -- for example, in some testing situations.

trans-unit.source: classpath: Databases are treated as read-only databases, relative to the classpath directory. See for details.

seg-source.mrk: classpath: Databases are treated as read-only databases, relative to the classpath directory.
See <xref href="cdevdvlp91854.dita#cdevdvlp91854"></xref> for details.

target.mrk: classpath: Databases are treated as read-only databases, relative to the classpath directory.
See <xref href="cdevdvlp91854.dita#cdevdvlp91854"></xref> for details.

trans-unit.source: jar: Databases are treated as read-only databases. DatabaseNames might require a leading slash, because you specify them "relative" to the jar file. See for details.

seg-source.mrk: jar: Databases are treated as read-only databases.
DatabaseNames might require a leading slash, because you specify them "relative" to the jar file.
See <xref href="cdevdvlp24155.dita#cdevdvlp24155"></xref> for details.

target.mrk: jar: Databases are treated as read-only databases.
DatabaseNames might require a leading slash, because you specify them "relative" to the jar file.
See <xref href="cdevdvlp24155.dita#cdevdvlp24155"></xref> for details.

trans-unit.source: jar requires an additional element immediately before the database name:

seg-source.mrk: jar requires an additional element immediately before the database name:

target.mrk: jar requires an additional element immediately before the database name:

trans-unit.source: (pathToArchive)

seg-source.mrk: (pathToArchive)

target.mrk: (pathToArchive)

trans-unit.source: pathToArchive is the path to the jar or zip file that holds the database.

seg-source.mrk: pathToArchive is the path to the jar or zip file that holds the database.

target.mrk: pathToArchive is the path to the jar or zip file that holds the database.

trans-unit.source: For detailed reference about connection URL attributes and values, see "Setting attributes for the database connection URL" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citref"></ph>.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the use of the connection URL:

seg-source.mrk: The following example shows the use of the connection URL:

target.mrk: The following example shows the use of the connection URL:

trans-unit.source: Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:derby:sample");

seg-source.mrk: Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:derby:sample");

target.mrk: Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:derby:sample");
